text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - um we have not seen cases where that is curative. That is also another type of therapy that delays the progression of the cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So so for example, if your primary goal was to delay hormone therapy for as long as possible, like if you really wanted at all cost to avoid hormone therapy - Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the one thing that we could consider would be referring you to a radiation oncologist that specializes in the type of radiation called stereotactic radio therapy, which is a very sort of focused - Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - razor-sharp beam of radiation that targets one particular area and doesn’t really cause scattering of the x-rays to other areas. So it spares the normal tissues. Patient: Um Doctor: And we have people at this place that do that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um but I don’t want you to go into that therapy believing that this is also a potentially curative therapy. I think it could definitely cure the tumor in that one lymph node that we can see.

text: Healthcare Professional: Um um well let me see. (Laughing) Doctor: Sometimes we see your blood numbers for your liver and how they function, sometimes that gets a little bit screwed up. You could get diarrhea or constipation – Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Doctor: - depending on. And then um in point six percent of people you could get a seizure. Doctor: - than one as in we give this stuff all the time and people, knock on wood - Family Member: Yeah.

text: Patient: If, if, if, if – Doctor: So, if the hormones alone are making those get better, better, better, we give you the trial, I have no way to know did it do anything. So, we usually wait until the hormone stops working by itself. Family Member: And, that’s all just gauged by a PSA or do you do the – Doctor: It’s gauged by PSA as a screening and then, you know, at some point we would then just re-image you, too. Family Member: Hmm. Doctor: But, our experience is, as long as the PSA’s going down, usually the imaging is either getting better or staying stable. So. Patient: If the PSA is that reliable in terms of – Doctor: Ehhh, it’s reliable enough. I don’t know, it’s not unbelievably reliable, but Patient: But, if – Doctor: Rather than, you know, trying to give you a CAT scan every month. Patient: It’s, it’s, it’s unlikely that the PSA is going to go up if things are okay. Doctor: Yes.

text: Family Member: Any other tests that we need to know about? Blood work and bone biopsy? Doctor: That’s all what I can think of right now. Healthcare Professional: and recent scans. text: Family Member: I had a question about if it does cause nausea (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Does that last the full three weeks or does it taper off? Doctor: Oh no. Most – I would not expect you to have significant nausea at all. I am going to give you a prescription on you know Zofran in case you need it. But most people don’t need more than what we give them today, right. Okay, so it’s not expected. Once in a while I guess if you have a major reaction, it’s okay to have it - Family Member: And so - Doctor: My hope is if this is a lot of this flare-up from the pain from the cancer, then actually we should start seeing an improvement ah without having to do - Patient: Well, that’s what I didn’t know was - Doctor: You know, and what raised my bar of suspicion is how much of this adrenal mass grew. Doctor: If the same kind of growth is happening in the bones, then you know it sort of took off all of a sudden, frankly. Family Member: Uh hum, right. Doctor: That made me think maybe the rest of your pain, also this big pain flare-up that you’re experiencing might be problematic Patient: Well see that’s - Doctor: But bone disease is always very hard to see.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
